review.title: Basis Identification for Automatic Creation of Pronunciation Lexicon for Proper Names
review.abstract: Development of a proper names pronunciation lexicon is usually a manual effort which can not be avoided. Grapheme to phoneme (G2P) conversion modules, in literature, are usually rule based and work best for non-proper names in a particular language. Proper names are foreign to a G2P module. We follow an optimization approach to enable automatic construction of proper names pronunciation lexicon. The idea is to construct a small orthogonal set of words (basis) which can span the set of names in a given database. We propose two algorithms for the construction of this basis. The transcription lexicon of all the proper names in a database can be produced by the manual transcription of only the small set of basis words. We first construct a cost function and show that the minimization of the cost function results in a basis. We derive conditions for convergence of this cost function and validate them experimentally on a very large proper name database. Experiments show the transcription can be achieved by transcribing a set of small number of basis words. The algorithms proposed are generic and independent of language; however performance is better if the proper names have same origin, namely, same language or geographical region.

sections.heading: E. Comparison with Festival TTS G2P rule base
sections.text: Column 6 in Table III shows the phonetic transcriptions of names generated from the vocabulary (OOV) using the G2P rule base for the words used in the Festival TTS Engine13. Results show that the transcriptions generated with the proposed method are more accurate than those generated with the Festival TTS rule base. Proper names are also synthesized using these two types of transcriptions, with the results that (a) a transcription obtained using the method discussed in this paper and (b) the transcriptions produced using the G2P rule base used in Festival TTS proved to be perceptibly better. Perception testing was conducted by asking two people who were not involved in the basic transcription process to listen to the synthesized proper names and evaluate the better of the two names for each name (they had no idea what transcriptions were used in the synthesization process).

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: Research on automatic G2P transcription has shown promising results for the phonetic transcription of regular texts where G2P transcriptions follow certain rules. Generating phonetic proper name transcriptions where the G2P converter cannot be applied directly requires human effort. In this paper, an optimization approach for the automatic generation of proper name pronunciations was proposed. We construct a cost function first and the transcription problem is reduced to a minimization of the constructed cost function. Two algorithms for identifying the basis and deriving the conditions for the convergence of the cost function were proposed. Experimental results on real databases of proper names confirm the derived convergence conditions and thus show that the developed optimization framework contributes to reducing the day-to-day task of transcribing proper names. The formulated framework work is general, and therefore not limited to data bases of proper names, although the intrinsic naming was carried out on an intrinsic database.

sections.text: BASISIn linear algebra, a base B of vector space V is by definition a set of linear independent vectors that spans V completely. B = {b1,..., bm} is considered the basis of vector space V = {v1,..., vn}, if B has the following properties: • Linear independence property: If a1,..., are at the scalar and if a1b1 +... + ambm = 0, then inevitably a1 =... = am = 0. This results in b1,..., bm orthogonal or b1,... b2,... bm; • Voltage property: For each vk in V it is possible to select scalars, a1,..., one that vk = a1b1 +... + anbn.

Syntactic knowledge is acquired by observing the sequences that are formed for a name. • CC rejection The pronunciation of a telephone in a sequence of telephones depends on the adjacent telephones. sections.heading: APPENDIX C
sections.text: The names in the base are sorted in descending order of their lengths. For a word bi in the base, a set of all words bik, which are a subline of bi, is collected, Bi = {bi1, bi2,..., bik,..., Bi |}. If Bi is empty, bi is retained in the base. For words whose Bi is not empty, the elements of Bi are sorted in descending order of their lengths. A name bik of Bi is considered at a time and its position is fixed in the word bi. The rest of bi is filled with bik in the order in which they appear in Bi. At the end of this process, bi must have been formed completely or partially with the available elements in Bi.

G2P converters usually produce a significant number of mistakes when converting proper names which are often of a foreign origin [3].
Recently, Bonafonte et al [4] reported an average phonetic accuracy of 53% for proper names when a rule based methodology is used to construct a phonetic dictionary of proper names.
